abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts are substantial. Two main lessons are
            highlighted as follows. First, Serbia's Government had
            set an ambitious reform agenda, and the Ministry of Finance
            provided strong reform leadership across the social
            protection and health agenda. Specifically, Serbia's
            Ministry of Social Affairs was the main driver of reforms,
            both in pensions and social welfare, and child protection,
            and this is where the reform outcomes have been most
            impressive. This clearly demonstrates that policy
            development lending achieves most impressive outcomes in
            situations where the Bank flexibly responds to a strong
            reform-minded Government. It also shows the difference in
            results and impact between cases where a counterpart is
            actively shaping the process, and setting the agenda for
            technical assistance and its follow-up, and those where
            counterparts are not in the driver's seat, but wait for
            the Bank's push. Second, with part of the task team
            based in Europe at the time of preparation, the Bank was
            able to effectively support the Government in the pursuit of
            its ambitious reform agenda in the areas of pension, health
            and social welfare reforms. This extended staff in-country
            presence, and extensive and flexible availability of a
            stable core team, helped the Bank in effectively responding
            to Government requests for support, in a period of ambitious reform.
